the Nevermore-class privateer vessel was primarily built in the secret shipyards of the Monolith coalition, although some of its parts can be traced to outside sources. It boasts twelve rapid-fire point defense "Blizzard"-type railguns, as well as eight medium-weight "Lightning Storm" type railguns. It boasts a small missile armament near the nose, capapble of launching eight bomb-pumped laser missiles simultaneously. Its primary engine was built in the secret Monolith yards, but spectrographic analysis shows it to be an antimatter-fuelled inertial confinement engine, a formidable weapon in its own right. A unique feature of the Nevermore is its ability to land and even hover over planetary surfaces, thanks to the four swivelling jet pods, two mounted in each wing. These serve a double duty: in space, they remain spinning and are used as massive gyroscopes to keep the ship amazingly stable while its guns are firing.
The Nevermore is currently captained by one Captain Eliza Black, with a crew of over one hundred, making it the most densely crewed ship in the Fleet. unlike any other vessels, with one notable exception, the Nevermore does not ever participate in large-scale fleet maneuvers, as its relatively small size and light armor would make it an easy target of opportunity. The ship is instead used as a privateer, for with its speed and accuracy, it can disable cargo haulers and other noncombatant ships without destroying them, and will then take their cargo.
The Nevermore is capable of 700 gravities of acceleration in space, and can reach speeds of up to 300 miles per hour in atmosphere. its four Mk12 Lightning-pattern laserdrive engines each can provide upwards of 600 million newtons of force. Its main cargo bay forms most of the rear of its hull, and can hold up to 1000 tonnes of payload. After a raid, this cargo tends to be booty, but before a battle the cargo bay can double as a staging area for the crew. It can even be stocked with cheap, disposable armored vehicles produced by the ship's internal 3D printer. These are recycled after an engagement and allow for even more cargo to be loaded.
The Nevermore is the spaceship equivalent of a playground bully, designed to take on defenseless ships much larger than itself, then get away cleanly before a fair fight develops.

title: Spacer for 20x20 Flight Controller and 4in1 ESC (Piko BLX, Mini Lux F4)

description.text:
Most if not all of the 4in1 6A and 10A ESC on the market use M3 hole and hardware, however the hex standoffs are too big and usually will hit SMDs on the board. This spacer is designed to replace the need to use M3 standoff. The height is 4mm, thin wall of only 0.8mm, the design is minimalistic and makes sure that there's enough space for wires etc to run in between the ESC and the FC.

Recommended configuration
Use a nylon M3x16 screws, go through the bottom of the frame, spacer, ESC, spacer, FC, secure the top with a nut or another short M3 standoff. Total height of the stack is between 10mm-12mm.

title: Neo Geo Pocket Color CR2032 Coin Cell Battery Cover

description.text:
Many Neo Geo Pockets have come to find themselves without coin cell battery covers over the years. If yours is missing, then this is for you.

This will fit the Neo Geo Pocket (NGP) and Neo Geo Pocket Color (NGPC), but not the Neo Geo Pocket Color Slim (NGPC Slim). It may also fit other devices with similarly designed CR2032 coin cell battery covers.

This design shouldn't require the use of a coin to open or close the cover, though a slot is included in order to function like the original. The ones I have printed have been snug enough to stay in place when closed but allow you to open and close them simply by pushing a bit and turning with your fingers.

I've printed several of these without supports and they work fine, though they may look a little weird. Using supports is recommended, though.

For an excellent NGPC AA battery cover, see funerall's design here. See also my remix of that design to fit the NGP here.

title: Soldering Helper for Pagoda Antennas by Maarten Baert

description.text:
So Maarten Baert designed the wonderful pagoda antennas people talk about. And since I ordered a huge bunch of PCBs I needed a more comfy soldering solution. So I drew this soldering helper. You just arrange your PCBs with it, solder a few spots, take everything out, Solder it freehand and continue with the next PCB.

(Maarten's Pagoda Page: http://www.maartenbaert.be/quadcopters/antennas/pagoda-antenna/ )

I printed it in 0.15mm PLA with 100% infill and no supports at all.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2 Blower Fan Adaptor

description.text:
Wanhao i3 blower fan adapter (Fits: Delta BFB1012H Blower Fan) (you can use the two bolts from the original 30x30 fan) fits 12v blowers with an outlet in the range of 58mm x 32mm (commonly used as CPU coolers in computers), It works great and at 50% the fan noise is virtually non-existent whilst providing a very strong current of air through the existing part-cooling assembly.

Edit: If you intend on using the same spec fan I as have in the picture remember to slice your models with the fan speed set at 46%, if not, the printer defaults to maximum, this causes a significant amount of air to pushed out badly warping your first few layers and excessively cooling the hot end.

description.text:
Hey everyone! I created this bracket mount from the two source files I've acknowledged in my sources. This allows you to print the LCD screen cover for the RepRapDiscount Smart LCD Controller file, while mounting it to the top of the FolgerTech 2020 Prusa i3, via the aluminum parframe. Pretty straightforward print.

I'll edit it over time, but as for printing standards, just use whatever you typically use. I went with the default settings for my printer and had okay results.

I've included both the .STL and .SLDPRT files for your use.

FolgerTech 2020 Prusa i3
I used Solidworks to edit the files for the bracket mount and the LCD screen itself.

author: pevesa

description.text:
A lampshade / tealight cover.

It's made of separate pentagons, you need to print 11 of them (If you want to keep just the bottom open. When using with tealights, it may be a good idea to keep the top open also.) and glue them together.

I also added a filled out single layer version that's more suitable for usable lighting (good with white filament). There are parts for the bottom and for the base, but they are based on my specific bulb holder, so they probably won't be compatible with anything else :)

If you like the design and think it's worth a dollar or two, a tip would be greatly appreciated. It would help me design more stuff and post it here.

This is a great case I designed and printed for the new Inductrix FPV. It will hold the Inductrix, 20 batteries, 7 USB chargers and has a slot for miscellaneous cables and tools. The lid has a big Tiny Whoop logo on it. I am not sure of the clearance for the other camera configurations with antenna, etc. The clearance of the lid is 30mm and the Inductrix sits 25mm in the base. If your quad is less than 55mm tall, it should fit with no issue.

Lid:
-Print time around 11 hours
-Print with the Whoop logo to the bed.
-Nozzle temp is 225, bed is 60.
-.4 nozzle
-25% infill
-Use support under the logo of 25%
-3 solid top layers, 3 solid bottom layers, 2 perimeter

Base:

-Print with the base on the bed.
-Nozzle temp is 225, bed is 60.
-.4 nozzle
-25% infill
-3 solid top layers, 3 solid bottom layers, 2 perimeter
-100% fan after the second layer

Same as the MaxiWhoop frame provided by sepion; but I've chopped the base of the motor holders off, because:

  • I can slide the motors in from the bottom
  • I can secure and protect the bottom of the motors with heatshrink tubing.
  • Easier to print - pulling the supports out of the motor mounts before was pretty impossible.
  • I can sit the motors at a custom height (to pull props further into the duct if desired)

Supports required, but easily accessible to remove.
Secure the flight controller/receiver with tape or zipties etc.

title: Metric Hole Test Pattern
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a metric hole test pattern that I developed years ago when I was doing more work with Shapeways. It is a flat, 3 millimeter thick piece with standard metric drill bit size holes, and can be used just as a decoration, or to measure detail, accuracy, and distortion (holes and flatness) in printed materials. It's also useful for judging the printed sizes of clearance or tap holes, or choosing a hole size to match a part you already have. The holes range in size from 1mm to 3mm in 0.1mm steps, and from 3mm to 10mm in both 0.1mm steps and 0.25mm steps. The holes are arranged in such a way as to require as little material as possible, and this was actually a bit of a challenge. After struggling with the math for quite a while, I ended up using a physics simulation library for the ideal placement. I think the result is quite pleasing to the eye. There is a cleaner key available on my blog site here: http://www.thefrankes.com/wp/?p=2100

1) Print.
2) Admire.
3) Smile.
4) Extra credit: Print another one and give it as a gift to someone you love. Be sure to include a mysterious yet strangely enticing note that emphasizes the object's worldly significance. The holes are organized in Ã¢â¬ÅrowsÃ¢â¬Â and placed as efficiently as possible in order to limit material use. This results in a unique and beautiful shape. There are also small bumps on the edges to indicate the odd (x.25 and x.75) measurements. There is a cleaner key available on my blog site here: http://www.thefrankes.com/wp/?p=2100 (For some reason it didn't upload well here.) You can find it on Shapeways here: http://www.shapeways.com/model/125875/metric_hole_test_pattern.html If you're really smart and up for a challenge, see if you can figure out a way using straight math to place all these circles so that they cover the smallest area possible, while still presenting them in an organized way.

comments.text: Nophead did something similar a while back. The problem when printing really small holes is the number of segments. He found there was a way to print really small holes accurately, by reducing the number of segments for small holes. See http://hydraraptor.blogspot.co.uk/2011/02/polyholes.htmlhttp://hydraraptor.blogspot.co...
comments.author: droftarts

comments.text: Yeah -- I think there's even a module for polyholes in the MCAD library for those that use OpenSCAD. Thanks for the comments!

I would recommend taking most of your material off the shorter top clip. If it is loose just put a dot or two of hot glue on the longer bottom rail and let it cool before sliding it on.

A brooch I made for my wife, modeled after a pendant she has but never wears.   
I figured "she never wears necklaces, but she does wear brooches, so let me make one that will work as a brooch!"  
I modeled this brooch in Blender, and after 3D printing, painting, and attaching a pinback, I gave it to her.  
She liked the effort but then explained that she didn't wear the pendant because she just bought it for the chain it came with, not the actual pendant.  
Oh well.  
I showed it to a guy a work and he said "it looks like it's from the movie Metropolis", thus my naming of the item.   
The original pendant wasn't quite so Art Deco-ish/Machine Age-ish; I made it more-so be keeping it a bit simpler and adding a stair-step to the bars.

Using my Form 1, I printed the main brooch on it's own, then all "gems" (1 large gem, 4 small gems) as close as I could to get PreForm to put them all on a single base. I printed each at an 30-degree (or so) angle. This allowed me to easily spray each item with Krylon for Plastic White Matte Primer.  
I left the gems on the supports and painted with 4-5 coats of Testor brand enamel paint, letting each dry completely.  
The main part I painted with 2-coats of a silver paint I had.  
I then used model glue to attach the gems to the main part, as well as the pinback to the backside.  
As an afterthought, I should have wiped a layer of thinned black paint on the silver part to make it appear more "aged".

title: cable tray for a wire rack shelf

description.text:
My 3d printer sits on a wire rack cart.
I have made a bunch of stuff to hang my tools and things from this cart.
I remixed the cable tray then remixed it again.
I added my own supports to the rail clips so they print nice. Cut off the supports post print.

Now I have 4, 2, and a 1 finger section of cable tray that will clip onto the front of my wire rack shelf.

The front rails measure 27mm outside measurement. The wires that make up the shelf are 20mm's on center.

I printed these with my standard ABS settings for heat and speed and 20% infill.

title: 2x Laptop or mobile phone repair screw sorting trays
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated! 7x5 tray added

These are two screw trays for use when dismantling laptops or mobile phones.

The idea is that the screw you remove goes in the tray in a similar position to the place the screw was removed from, for example on the bottom of a laptop, the top left screw would go in the top left corner recess, the bottom middle screw in the bottom middle recess and so on.

If required, you can glue a small magnet to the underside of each recess.

This should help when reassembling the laptop as it should jog your memory.

No supports or rafts are required if printed in the supplied orientation.

And no they cannot be used to bake small cakes..............

title: Espresso Adjustable Palm Tamper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Palm Tamper with Adjustable Depth Control...

Tamp is 58.8mm...

Threads wound up being very snug. I didn't want a lot of slop...so I fear I may have made it dimensionally a bit too tight. I had to work the components back and forth to get the threads to move more freely...but they still wind up tight. I may try some food grade silicone grease on them to see if it helps. Ideally, I need to put just a bit more room in future iterations.

I made this THING as a proof of concept...I"ll be testing it with my old dilapidated Hamilton Beach Espresso machine --- I have a Rocket Espresso Appartamento coming in March(2017)...so I will remix and post the design again...to the dimensions of the Rocket Portafilter Baskets...

Enjoy!!!!

EDIT:

I have found that working the components back and forth with one another has made the threads run much smoother. When I thread the tamp into the backside of the main body...it spins on freely. I believe there is some drag from the walls of the tamp, when threaded into the main body. I have lightly sanded the outer diameter of the tamp to reduce this friction...and it's getting there. I may throw in a little more wall clearance on the next iteration.

NOTE: Because this is an accessory for making espresso...it should be printed with a food grade filament for use in food prep. I'm just testing the design using PLA at this time.

Work the threads...

This design has very tight tolerances on the threaded portion. It needs to be worked back and forth to get it to move more freely. It still has too much resistance...as it shouldn't be a chore to make adjustments as necessary without tools. I'll need to remix the thread clearances to make them easier to use.

comments.text: FDM is not really suited for food grade applications without post processing, no matter if its food grade filament or not. Such an object is porous like a sponge and it will get infested with bacteria over time on the inside. Vapor smoothing would be a possible option, to seal the outer layer and/or applying food grade paint, to do the same.

title: Head cooling Fan Holder for Makerbot Mk6

description.text:
A parametric fan holder to hold a cooling fan for a Makerbot. Great for keeping the PLA cool in the pipes.
This is my first go at a fan holder. And a project to learn OpenSCAD. I got my inspiration from thing 11546, but created this thing from scratch.

Adjust the parameters as required, print with full supports, drop it onto the bolts on the top of the extruder assembly, add a fan and you're done.
It is set up for a 60mm fan. You may need to insert your own measurements to get it to work with whatever fan you have lying around.
The file is tweaked to print on a makerbot that has lots of trouble with the X axis so the bolt holes are set a lot larger than they should be.
I am still getting used to OpenSCAD so the code is not all that pretty but I thought that it might be useful to someone out there.

title: DRACK vape atomizer and box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
First fully printed rebuildable drip atomizer.
Contains from two pieces and the box with cover.
Feel free to customize the idea.
Solidworks files are attached, so any improvements are welcome.
Work in progress.

https://youtu.be/OUa3Si-iuP0

If you are not a jerk, it's safe, but use your own brain together with this vape box, please. Even a teaspoon is dangerous in moron's hands, so don't be an idiot. Use only at your own risk and always be careful. Thanks.

And sorry for my English.

Printer:

3Drack

Resolution:

.2 layer height at .4 nozzle, use automatic or .5 layer width

Infill:

100%

Notes:

ABS, ASA, PET or something with high heat resistance required - PLA has a too low melting point and probably will not work.

Make a coil.

Make a coil from a kanthal wire. Use only pure cotton wool and make few threads with it. Make sure that the wire is isolated with a cotton from the sides of plastic atomizer.
Use ohms law calculator to compute resistance of the coil!
I used a flat resistance wire which is hard to break, but if you have nothing like that at home, I'll give you a small hint - consider your mum's hairdryer exploration ;-)

Place the coil.

Fit ends of the coil to the two small terminals and stretch thin wires through the holes at the bottom. Use rather thin wires with teflon insulation and jam holes with hot glue from the bottom. Get a tweezers and you'll be done in a minute.

Wire it up.

Use some connectors and button (or rather a relay, mosfet or something). I'm using the 3S lipoly to power the vaping box, but 2S will work as well, but remember to make a proper coil.

Drip juice.

Drip some e-juice inside. Cotton must we wet, but too much juice doesn't work. Play with it and you will find the best level soon.

Place the top.

Use a shrinking tube on the insertion part of the top to seal pieces. Or you can scale the top to 104% and the top will fit itself.

Enjoy.

It's free, opensource and cheap, so you have to make some experiments to make it work well. But with some care you will get a working piece of smoking fun.

comments.author: WarHawk8080

comments.text:
It is simple. You can simply google "vape box wiring" - there are a lots of options - you can use only a button (which is not good, because there is a lots of amps and you can burn it's contacts. Better solution is using a MOSFET switch. There is a lots of space inside.
I used 3S 1000mAh lipo battery with t-deans connector - there is no holder, just put it inside.
But don't worry, I will add more instructions and photos in few days.

description.text:
---CONTEST ANNOUNCEMENT!---

Netherforged Design Contest: I've been hard at work cranking out these Netherforged Dwarven Constructs lately, and frankly, I only have so many ideas. So, we've decided to hold a contest. Take a look through the existing designs in the collection and come up with your own dwarven automaton, siege weapon, or similar contraption, email your sketches/descriptions to us at [email protected] (Subject: Netherforged Design Contest) and, if we pick yours, I'll design it, print it, paint it, post it, and ship it to you. Deadline is February 25th, so get to your idea-anvil and start hammering!

This character was designed for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for our modular wargaming system, Wayfarer Tactics (now in Second Edition!).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

You can keep up to date on Netherforged pieces via this growing collection.

Enjoy!

title: Cyno02 Arduino Robot walker

description.text:
Cyno02 est un remix de cyno01 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2077834).
Mieux équilibré, plus rapide, il utilise un capteur à ultra son.
J'ai changé la marque des moteurs, les Topmodel sont remplacés par des Futaba.
Sa tête amovible lui permet de rechercher une issue plus rapidement en cas
de détection d'obstacle.
Sur la vidéo vous pourrez visualiser une courte démo des Cynos.
Après une rapide dance de bienvenue,
Cyno2 se déplace en gardant sa tête dans l'axe de son "déhanchement" :)

dans les pièces jointes j'ai déposé 4 ZIP :

  • Arduino-cyno2-v1-0.zip : Code principal pour l'Arduino
  • arduino_cyno2-tete.zip : Code pour ajuster le centre du servo Tête
  • arduino-cyno2-centre.zip : Code pour ajuster les centres des 4 servos Jambes et pieds.
    (La valeur des 5 calibrations devra être reporté dans le code principal)
  • freecad-CYNO2.zip : Les sources CAO sous FreeCAD.

Sa nomenclature
4 x Servo FUTABA S3001
1 x SG90 Micro servo
1 x Inter ref 700092 CONRAD
1 x Contact pression pour coupleur ref 624691 CONRAD
1 x COUPLEUR 6 R6 ref 615587 CONRAD
6 x pile AA 2300mAh
1 x ARDUINO UNO

2 x LED bicouleur ref 2285764 (RS)
6 x Résistance 220R

1 x C2 0.10µF

  • LED BICOULEUR D5mm GAUCHE TETE
    PIN 6 : Anode rouge
    PIN 5 : Anode VERT
  • LED BICOULEUR D5mm DROITE TETE
    PIN 10 : Anode rouge
    PIN 9 : Anode vert
    • 4 LED blanche D5mm sur le torse
      PIN 3;
    • Affectation des servos FUTABA S3001 pour les jambes et pieds
      PIN 2 : Servo Jambe Gauche
      PIN 13 : Servo Jambe Droit
      PIN 4 : Servo Pied Gauche
      PIN 7 : servo Pied Droit
  • Affectation micro servo SG90 pour la tete
    PIN 8
  • Pin pour capteur ultrason type HC-SR04
    PIN = 12 : Broche trigger
    PIN = 11 : Broche ECHO

description.text:
Power coupler for a Shopsmith for my friend Rich the Engineer.

While not a remix of Krunchys model it certainly was inspired by it.

Just like Krunchy says, use at your own risk. I have no idea if it is fit for your use, how long it might last, or whether it will break into 73 pieces, put your eyes out and kill your dog.

The printed part is a tight fit, and a few of the teeth, were shaved during installation.

Rich hooked this low fill (5%) POC test up, and tried it with a light load. It worked fine.

The next test is an ABS print with 8 shells and 50% fill.
(The resulting stl file would not convert to xg3 for my flash card)

If you make one, or have problems with it, I would love to hear about it.

I ended up getting some Filabot 910175 Taulman 910 Alloy filament.
It took a lot of tries to get things working right.
The real key is 255/65 temps, and slower speed.
It seemed to work best with 2 shells and a 50% fill.
I printed with fill to support the ceiling of the lower chamber.
Removing the fill tore part of the teeth off.
I redesigned the lower chamber to have a vaulted ceiling, so no support material was needed.
I printed it with a raft, and it still worked lose from the print bed.
Finally, as strange as it sounds, i added 8 rocket fins to help stablize it at the bottom.
I printed it at 30/30 speed with raft.

The print was 9 hours, and took 27.5 meters of the nylon filamant.
The fins were removed with an exacto knife.
The finished piece is strong.

I recommend stopping the print once you have one to two centimeters, and verify that the side hub fits. It may save you some filament.

This new model has the name _nylon on the end of it.

Let me know how it works out for you.

Notes:

I printed this in PLA at 200/60 degrees.
Use a RAFT with FULL Support
infill 100%
layer .20
shells 2
feedrate 50/50

Estimated print time 5.5 hours.
Filiment Cost is about 30 meters

title: "Perfection" game /w board and cover (dual extrusion)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
You can find the original puzzle pieces here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:267538

this bundle comes with:

  • 25 different puzzle pieces (in individual stl files and also in a single one)
  • board for single extrusion, or
  • board for dual extrusion (borders and the molds in two individual files)
  • cover for better storage / transportation (blank)
  • cover with the title and instructions on it (english or german)
  • cover text for dual extrusion (individual stl files)

the board is 162x162x9mm and the cover is 168x168x28mm big.
if it doesn't fit on your printer, you'll have to scale all parts (also the puzzle pieces) down by the SAME %, or they won't fit.

the tolerances should be enough to even serve a not perfectly calibrated printer :-)

PLEASE LEAVE A COMMENT, IF YOU LIKE IT :-)

======== Original Summary by SuperInfraMan ======

This is a set of the 25 geometrical shapes for the old Miltion Bradley "Perfection" game in which you have to place all pieces in their respective spaces in 60 seconds.
( https://www.amazon.com/Milton-Bradley-Perfection-1998-Board/dp/B003YVNNII )

At The Scrap Exchange in Durham, NC I found a functioning gameboard which had no game pieces remaining. I measured all the holes and designed pieces to fit.

Pieces 04hex and 05stickstar are a little bit small; I will adjust those and reupload when I have tested them.

This game is really too easy, so I think the next step will be to print them in glow plastic and play it in the dark.

Printer:

geeetech prusa i3 pro c

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm Layer hight

Infill:

5-20%

Notes:

Puzzle pieces:
20% infill

board & cover:
5% infill

Dual Extrusion:
you'll need "cover_engl.stl" and "cover_engl_text_only_for_dual_extrusion.stl" for the english version (guess what for the german one...).

both files are perfectly aligned, so just put them in your slicer, center them (automatically if possible) and you'll be fine

======== Original Instructions by SuperInfraMan ======

Print pieces as needed. All of them fit well if printed on a well-tuned printer; bottom edges may need a little scraping.
eye-hand coordination

1) Two children play against each other and write down the needed time
2) two groups of children could battle against each other
3) one single child can take a timeout, if it is stressed

  • printed parts (see above)
  • stopwatch

title: Twin Servo Plug for RC receiver

description.text:
The receiver on my RC car has 4 connector slots but only the inner two are used. I wanted to plug the outer ones so as not to get dirty. Also, one of the connectors - because of the way I zip tied the cables - is loose and sometimes it comes out by itself. With this twin connector based on the design of Motorpixiegimbals, modified for rigidity and to make it printable (my slicer doesn't print anything less than 0.4mm), I plug the empty slots and also - thanks to the tight fit and the horizontal connection - it keeps all plugs, well, plugged in.
The design includes the only supports needed (blue in the drawing) because my slicer was indeed exceedingly creative on this matter. Cut away the two thin parts (actually a H-section). (The No-Supports file is included only to show what has to be cut off). Also, the design has very little area to stick to the printing surface so a raft will be needed.

Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Yes

No

0.1

Infill:

100%

The design is thin so I don't think Infill matters.

author: ilias_12

description.text:
This is a simple fitting/couping for the Nema 17 motor (don't know if it works for the Nema 23 as well). I was making the "Simple filament extruder puller by james_III" and found some rubber wheels that had a 7mm diameter hole, but my Nema 17 motor shaft had a 5mm diameter so I needed some sort of "tube" to make the shaft fit thight on the rubber wheel hole. On the files attached you will find an .STL ready to print, and I also included the 123D design source files in case you want to modify the fitting to be used on a wheel or any other project that has a bigger diameter. Just use the "pull" function to make the tube thicker (it can't be made thinner, the walls are thin enough already).

You will find 2 versions of the fitting: V1 and V2.
V1: This drawing is supposed to represent a perfect fit, with a 5mm internal diameter hole and a 4.6mm to the flat point of the nema shaft, and a 7mm external diameter
V2: This drawing was slightly adjusted to actually fit the shaft. When you are printing, certain plastics tend to shrink when cooling and that shrinking caused that the V1 of the files did not fit my motor shaft, so I increased the size of the tube a bit and V2 actually fit quite well.

Corner and "floor" brackets for the enclosure I made of 4mm acrylic glass for my prusa i3.
The panels would have stuck together without the brackets I guess, but I wanted to play safe :)

title: Anet A8 Power supply cover w\LCD power meter

description.text:
I was looking for a power supply cover since the day I bought this wonderful 3d printer, because I don't like the exposed contacts and the lack of a main power switch.
In the meantime I decided to add something to monitor power consumption when printing, because... well mainly for fun :D

At first I bought a DC power meter but since power in DC is well beyond 10A I had to buy a bulky DC power meter, and it won't never fit the tiny space under the power supply. Also, I was thinking about using all the three pairs of DC outputs so measuring that way is not possible.

I then found a cheap AC power meter from china that was perfect.. the only problem was that due to size it will not fit again under the power supply. The only solution was to design my own power supply cover.
I took inspiration (for an artist it means copying) from many other projects here on Thingiverse and I added mine as a remix of those. Thanks for your great work guys!

This is the cool 'n' cheap power meter I used, I paid about 7 dollars for it:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/222200638853?_trksid=p2055119.m1438.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

I also used an IEC socket with O\I lighted button, found at a local electronic fair but you can find on ebay easily.
In the next section I'll try to show you how to wire them up.

PLEASE NOTE: I have the first version of the Anet's power supply, marked 250w. I believe the 240w has the same size so it would be ok too, but probably not on the 180w version (if it exists).

A small video showing the LCD and some other mods I have (OctoPrint and relay board in action)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VwHwLKdr_Z0

Check out all my Anet A8 projects:

  • Anet A8 Prusa i3 Simple filament guide (Horizontal) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764285
  • Anet A8 RPi Camera Bed mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1867549
  • Anet A8 Y Axis Cable Chain v2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1915486
  • Anet A8 hotbed thermal insulation http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1917197
  • Anet A8 Power supply cover w\LCD power meter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2087761
  • Anet A8 Z-Axis RPi Camera mount for panning timelapses http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2265949
  • Anet A8 LED Illumination MOD http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2285674
  • The One - Anet A8 - Universal Spool Holder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2456038

Printer:

Anet A8 (Prusa i3)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Even if Simplify3D creates supports under the diagonal part under the display, in my many tries I discovered that this isn't really needed. The only support needed is the one on the left side, where the cable from the Z-axis motor will go through. You need to place supports manually there, at least with Simplify3D.
Look at the screnshot I uploaded to better understand.

Wiring

Wiring this is really easy.
Wires go from IEC connector to the switch, and then to the AC IN connectors on the power meter. Then from it two wires go to the power supply IN connectors.
Look the pictures below to better understand.

I just uploaded a hand-drawn schematics - it's not a piece of art but should clarify the simple wirings needed :)

LCD AC power meter Schematics. Picasso's hand-drawn schematics with wirings From IEC connector to switch, to power meter Almost done All connected Installing on the power supply

I used an allen key screw I had as a spare that come with the printer, it's an M3 screw about 47mm long. Simply remove the screw near the "L" header and screw it in. The new screw you have left now can be used on the right side :)

comments.text: Pardon me if my question is stupid as I might be lacking some understanding. But don't we need a DC meter since we're measuring DC voltage? Like this one, that has a range of 0 to 50A: http://www.ebay.ca/itm/LCD-DC-6-5-100V-20A-50A-100A-Combo-Panel-Display-Volt-Amp-Power-Watt-Meter-/332182273215?var=&hash=item4d579b3cbf:m:mFd4dGoSkLGjjWRH5-mjDQQ
comments.author: corsara

comments.text:
If you are measuring AFTER the power adapter, yes, since it transforms the 220\110V AC to 12V DC. So measuring after transformation requires the meter you linked. At first I thought about measuring DC, but that meter comes with that bulky resistor bar and a difficult wiring scheme, so I reverted to measuring AC.
In my project I'm measuring AC power, BEFORE the power adapter - the 220\110V AC coming from wall outlet. The benefit is a simplier wiring scheme, no bulky resistors and the actual power consumption of the printer. In fact, measuring DC, we will miss the power percentage wasted inside the power adapter by transforming AC to DC.
comments.author: corsara

comments.text: Oh, got it, thank you for the explanation, now I understand!   Ok, one more question:  is measuring the AC current (before the power supply) indicative to what current is going from the power supply towards mainboard and mosfet?  I'm mainly concerned with monitoring what current goes through that wire.
comments.author: papinist

comments.text: If you are concerned with the current going though a specific DC wire, I recommend getting a current meter.  The simplest of them have a plastic clip section that goes around the wire and will tell you the current running through it from induction. I always find it is better to err on the side of safety with larger wires, especially since you aren't running that far at all. I have 2 runs of 14 awg wire coming from the power supply to the mosfets for the heated bed and hot end.  Then the included 18 awg wire powering the board.  That should be more than sufficient without having to worry about current. Though getting at least one mosfet or relay for the heated bed is definitely recommended. Heed the advice of the other users who have had fire issues powering everything through the mainboard.
comments.author: corsara

comments.text:
Yes of course it is indicative even if not 100% accurate due to the percentage wasted in transformation. (we need to know the power adapter efficiency to get the exact numbers but I bet it is in the 80-90% range)
For example I can see that with only raspberry ON my power consumption is 0.06A @ 220V AC, If you know something about electronic formulas (and I'm not one of those guys) you can do simple math to have the A @ 12V DC.
comments.author: corsara

comments.text: Excellent, thank you for the info! Conveniently, there are calculators online for the lazy people like me, like this one: https://www.batterystuff.com/kb/tools/ac-to-dc-amperage-conversion-run-through-an-inverter.html

The printer PSU is not powered all the time, it is on only when I manually switch the switch on the back. In this way I can have all off, only the Pi on or all on.

I think the goal should be that it works like a paper printer - always on in some sleep mode but turns itself to full power when needed.
comments.author: papinist

comments.text:
Sure, for that you can keep the mechanical switch always on.
You don't want printer psu powered all the time, but you want to print remotely so something should be on - like a paper printer. Also regular printers has a 'mains' that you will keep on ON position, then ther printer goes to standby. Think at this the same way: switch on ON position, raspberry is powered and ready to listen to your commands, either local or remote, to switch on the printer and start printing.
Pi uses only a few milliamp when it is doing anything.
comments.author: anverx

comments.text: If you shutdown the printer, the meter shutdown to? and erase everything? have a memory?
comments.author: Piero87

comments.text:
When shutting down the printer (via relay board controlled by Octoprint's menu) the meter is still active to monitors the raspberry's power consumption. When shutting down the main power (via the rocker switch at the back) the meter goes off but it has memory and keeps in memory the total W used.
You can of course reset this counter via long press on the only button available. You can also set an alarm if W used exceeds a specified amount - but I don't think this is of any use in this application :)

Your springs are obviously too weak for the classic antibacklash nut made of two nuts.
Here as you use a polymer somewhat elastic open nut, it can be made with no play, no backlash and therefore no need for the brass nut, spring, screws etc..., just the polymer nut !

I recently upgraded to a chimera clone. This is the parts i needed to make the swap.

Printer is a Max Micron I3.

The fan holder has the mounting holes off center. This is because it has to match the holes on the chimera block. My guess is that since these are so far off center they will not match yours. Simple fix in tinkercad should have you up and going.

The X Carriage. I moved the auto level sensor mount up to account for the shorter hotend. I added several different holes to mount the adaptor because by the time i switched i had several holes drilled and tapped in my old x carriage. the holes do not have the nut inlay i just ran an m3 tap through all of the holes and was careful not to overtighten the screws. I also added a horn on top so i had something to zip tie the wires to.

The adaptor plate is pretty simple. Notice that the hole pattern, i do not believe it will line up with a legitimate chimera hot end only the clones.

The chimera i got was $40 on amazon that is why i am assuming it is a clone.

I printed with ABS at 75% infill with 1.2 walls/top/bottom. I see no reason why PLA would not work.

author: Looooopy

title: Wanhao i3 Control Box backplate / rear cover for 70mm fan

description.text:
I wanted a new rear cover for my Wanhao i3 printer control box to hold a bigger fan than the stock one, and also to move the wiring loom to gain a few extra inches as my control box is under my printer which is in an Ikea Lack Cabinet.

having looked through many on Thingiverse, I decided to design my own to encompass all the features I wanted - Which were...

  1. Must take the biggest fan possible
  2. must not stick out the back
  3. must relocate the printer wiring loom to the top instead the bottom
  4. must not have to cut or reshape the mains connector

My Thing accomplishes all my goals and seems to work well :)

You will need two 10mm m3 screws with washers and nuts to hold the Mains connector in place, and also the four standard fan screws to hold the fan in place.

I also had to move the PSU back a little further (30mm) inside the case to make way for the wires.
To do this, remove the PSU, and mark out the new position of the four holes, 30mm towards the rear of the PSU case and very carefully drill them out with a 2.5mm drill through just the outer case. The original screws will self cut into the aluminium psu case.

I also had to put a 60 ohm resistor in line with the fan to slow it down a little as running at full power it was quite noisy.

title: Magnetic IKEA desk clip for USB cables and more

description.text:
Magnetic cable receptable clip (two parts, just push together when printed) that will stop your USB cables (and more, presumably) from dropping down the side of the desk.

There's lots of cable guides out there already but none that would have a low impact on the desk and would allow me to use the sides of my desk, rather than the back. And I could have used one that clips on, but I wanted to experiment with magnets.

So this one's got a 10mm x 6mm void in the middle of the print. Just pause the print before it does the last layer or two, lift the print head up, drop in your magnets, put the print head back where it was, and resume your print. Providing your extruder is not magnetic, this will continue on just fine.

Print the two pieces, push together, make sure you've dropped your magnets in whilst printing, and then slot your cable through. Job done.

10mm gap inside circle for cable, 3mm gap to push the cable through if you need to. Glue two pieces together for permeance if required.

I rushed the finishing just to see if it would fit. So don't judge my filing/sanding skills!

Also I removed the sunken text from the top, seems like it messes up quite a bit on my printer due to it being so small.

Update: added the base plate, a final version of the keyboard base and a floppy box model.

This is a miniature model of a classic Amstrad PC1640 I made to house an oled screen and a ESP32 micro controller. I started this project to see if I could model a complex object with its real life measurements then scale it down for printing with openSCAD.

To build it you will need a long (~30mm) M4 screw and Nut. I recommend some rubber feet or a piece of 1mm rubber sheet since that is what I tend to use on all my prints nowadays to keep them from sliding around. It should be fine without it tho.

For the electronics you will need 2 3mm leds (red and green) as well as some kind of microcontroller to drive your display - I used an esp32 and an esp8266.
I included mounting inserts into the monitor for the common .96" and 1.3" OLED modules you can find on amazon and aliexpress.

I will add some more details in the next few days and maybe a link or two to the matching displays and boards.

Printer:

CTC Prusa i3 Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1-.2 see picture for recommendations

Infill:

40 to 100% depending on part

Notes:

Printing of these parts can be tricky and active cooling is a must for the finer details to come out right. All of the Models are oriented in the way they are supposed to be printed. For ease of printing I added an alternative version of the monitor front but I personally prefer the version with supports since its mechanically more sturdy.
To make everything look good i recommend sanding it with 240 grid WET sandpaper.

Sanding and Preperations

As mentioned earlier you should sand the parts with 240 grid wet sandpaper. If you start with say a bit of 180 grid then it goes faster. The sandpaper will give the base a nice matte finish (at least with the white PLA i used). The monitor back is a bit of a pain to sand tho and needs a lot of work. The Monitor front needs careful work to bring out the subtle curve it should have. the smaller parts need some light sanding to make them look good and fit better together when getting glued later.

Painting

Adding some opaque paint is important since the PLA I used (and the other PLA i tried to a degree) is either slightly translucent or would show the strong light of a LED directly behind it especially if the Room is dark. Also inlays (like the one for the inner part of the case front) will shine through where it has tabs to hold it in place. To prevent this from happening a bit of white paint in the notches and on the tabs is needed(see picture).

Add a bit of paint to the notches of the front

For maximum effect you should add a layer of black paint after 2 layers of white paint. it is also completely fine to fill the LED pinholes with paint - they can be easily cleared after the paint has dried with a needle or a nozzle drill and it will massively improve the look in dark environments since the pinholes become very well defined by this.
If you use a micro with bright LEDs on it you might add a layer of paint to the inside of the monitor as well.

Gluing the parts

There are several parts that need gluing depending on what models you printed. The front of the case consists of 2 parts that fit into each other snugly and need to be glued on the tabs and the upper flat part to hold together when putting the drives in.

remember to add some glue to the top where there are no tabs

Once this is dry you glue them to the back of the case. You can then give the combined parts a light sanding to remove any slight misalignment between the parts.
I glued the monitor spacer to the base but that part is entirely optional since the screw will hold the spacer in place regardless once the model is assembled.
The captive screw holder needs also to be glued into the monitor. It can be used either with a regular or self-securing m4 screw.

If you want to have the closed drive light up you will have to glue the LED holder to the closed floppy drive. Please make sure you have painted the back of the floppy sufficiently and put in a piece of a floppy that you colored so its visible (I like to use red here because its easy to see and the Amstrad system disk was this color out of the box) into it. The floppy in the closed floppy drive model is not removable.

Electronics

title: 3Drag: improved y-axis linear bearing holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've had some problems with ripples in my prints or even missed steps. After some investigation and experimentation I found out that the reason seems to be the sturdiness of the y-axis linear bearing holders - or rather the lack of such. Because the holders are just held by one screw each, they can be slightly tilted, not holding the bearings in an exact straight line. This causes them to block movement and makes the printing bed jerk around (just a little, but that's enough to cause some trouble) instead of sliding nicely. (This was accompanied by a rattling sound. If you have similar problems, maybe you've heard that.)

The quick and cheap solution I found, was to just design and print new linear bearing holders for the y-axis. You can download the model here - maybe it'll help you.

--

Update (15.03.17): There was a problem with the size of the model in the .stl file. I reuploaded a fixed version.

remixed_from.author: DarthBane
remixed_from.title: Cell Phone Spring Loaded Tripod Mount

title: Taller Cell Phone Spring Loaded Tripod Mount, ninjaflex grippers and better threads for mount

description.text:
I printed the cell phone spring loaded tripod mount, and found my phone is larger and thicker (extra capacity battery) than what it could hold. On top of that, my tripod has rather short threads, so I couldn't use the embedded 1/4" nut. So, I visited my local hardware store to look for options. I selected a little longer spring and a 1/4" thread insert (for wood). (spring is the same 3/8" OD, length is more like 2 3/4") Keep the spring under 2 3/4" so the spring keeps the whole assembly tight.

The grippers must be printed in Ninjaflex, otherwise the retention bulbs will not flex for installation. I printed in PLA, if you print in other materials you may need to scale the files to account for shrinkage different than PLA. The retention bulbs are necessarily hard to insert so they stay in place, so if your material shrinks a lot they could be impossible to insert.

The mount is re-designed to take the threaded insert after printing so I wouldn't need to interrupt printing and it brings the threads to the edge of the part so my tripod would work. You need to print 2 grippers in ninjaflex, and of course 2 spring pins. (read DarthBane's instructions too, this one goes together pretty much the same way)

After printing the bottom mount, install the thread insert with the slot going in first so it cuts into plastic as it goes in. You will need an insertion tool, so fully thread the insert onto a 1/4" bolt and use that to turn the insert into the plastic. This process takes a lot of force, don't try to do it by hand. Turn it down until the threaded insert is flush with the bottom of the mount and remove the installation tool (the 1/4" bolt). Installing the spring is tricky because it is under tension once installed. Thread a loop of string, as pictured, through the insert and over the spring hook. Pull the string, aligning the assembly as the parts come together, until the spring hook is in position and insert the spring pin.

The grippers are installed with a blunt pin. (a 1.5 mm ball end hex key works well) Push the pin into the hole on the face of the gripper (opposite the retention bulb). Align the bulb with the retention hole on the mount and push the bulb into the hole using the blunt pin. The pin elongates the bulb allowing it to be forced through the retention hole. Once the gripper is fully seated, remove the blunt pin and the gripper will stay where it is.

author: Zacken

description.text:
I remodeled it in Solidworks and filleted the edges properly and made the tolerances a little tighter. I didn't like the conical screw hole as I was using the standard M3 bolts that came with my ToM, so I simply countersunk them. I gave the tensioning 'tower' part a little more beef. I still had to slightly drill out the main 4 screw holes, but the M3 screw whole for the tensioner part fit perfectly.
I also added a small plate to replace the cork as I wanted this motor to slide when I tightened the tensioning bolt. The overall dimensions I believe are a tad too big, as I still had to sand/file down some sides to really make it fit perfectly. Maybe someone else will have better success with it. Maybe my scaling was off when I printed it. Let me know! After installing, my print quality went WAAY up. Circles are now actual circles, not weird polygons.

You will have to remove the motor completely. Remove the cork spacer as this will cause the motor to stick. Installation layers are as follows: Tensioner Part 1
Wood Y-carriage
Tensioner Part 2 (simple flat plastic spacer/slider)
Nema 17 motor I had a little blue locktite on the M3 bolts holding the motor already. I tightened down the bolts through the plastic parts just snug enough that it still allowed my to slide the entire assembly by tightening the tensioning screw. You can then tighten down the main 4 bolts after it is place if you really want to.

2/11/17 9:19 PM: Yeah the final version is being posted really late from when I said it would be but ITS HERE! Now sturdier with four pegs that actually fit into the holes!

Holding one pair of calipers per every two inches was a bit too inefficient for my FRC team's tastes, so I redesigned a bit and now we can fit six pairs of calipers in 4 inches of space, by mounting them sideways.

If after printing, the pegs are too small to fit properly into your board, maybe try wrapping some kind of tape around them to thicken them up. If, they don't fit into the hole at all, take some clippers and trim down the outer edges of the pegs. I have also included the Inventor Part file so that you may edit it and make your own STL files to fit your specifications.

Remember to print with supports, and to cut the supports off when done printing.

title: i3 A8 Cura Golden Ratio for Speed & Quality

description.text:
This is a Cura slicer profile, which claims to be optimized for a balance in speed & quality, only for the newer v.2.
I have no idea where I originally found this file, it's not mine.
I had been using Cura v.14, which came with my printer. I found it more user friendly than the new v.2. However, after finding this profile on the web somewhere, I started using v.2 again.
I've been very satisfied with mods & replacement parts I have printed using this profile, & I've become more comfortable with v.2 now.
Nothing is locked in, you can still change functions.
Test cube included.

It can be used with any size or brand printer.

print_settings.Notes:: The battery door was a problem in ABS: the spring section would print as a gummy mess with the two sides fused together, even when slowed down to 8 seconds/layer. To address this I added the Tower of Distraction (a cylinder with the same height as the spring section) to be placed somewhere else on the bed, so the extruder would spend some time away from the spring section and the plastic would have a chance to cool. In PLA it prints without any need for the Tower. Nylons might or might not need it, haven't tested.

description.text:
This is a case for another clone of the GM328 tester - in this case from EZM Electronics Studio. The board has just M328 as the model number, but the firmware says GM328.

I wanted one that would expose the surface mount testing pads since I work with a lot of SMT stuff. Requires no fasteners, everything snaps together. The battery fits under the screen board in a compartment with a door.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed in ABS, extruder temp 245C (I think my hotend runs a little cooler than commanded) with a retrofitted heated bed (Kapton with PVA coat) at 110C.

The battery door was a problem in ABS: the spring section would print as a gummy mess with the two sides fused together, even when slowed down to 8 seconds/layer. To address this I added the Tower of Distraction (a cylinder with the same height as the spring section) to be placed somewhere else on the bed, so the extruder would spend some time away from the spring section and the plastic would have a chance to cool. In PLA it prints without any need for the Tower. Nylons might or might not need it, haven't tested.
For the ABS part I found it was helpful to use a hot air pencil/heat gun on the spring section to get better fusion between layers on the outside. This made it a lot more durable.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed with Taulman t-glase black, extruder 250C (I think my hotend runs a little cooler than commanded), bed 45C, Kapton with PVA. I printed with 0.1mm resolution so the curves would look nice, but 0.2mm would probably work as well. It works best to print "upside down" with the locking features upward. This reduces the amount of support needed considerably and gives a smoother surface to mate with the brew basket, which means less coffee escapes.

title: Krups XP4030 espresso packing guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a time-saving device for making espresso: instead of grinding coffee into a container, then pouring it into the brew basket, and doing multiple rounds of packing to prevent spillage, you can just twist-lock this onto the basket assembly, grind directly into it, and pack with no coffee wasted except for a little bit in the corners. It's designed for my 10-year-old Krups XP4030, but would probably work with a lot of other 52mm machines.

My tamper is a little small (51.3mm diameter) so I made the bore 51.6mm in the model, and it has a nice fit when printed with Taulman t-glase - tight enough to keep the tamper square so the coffee gets packed flat, but not so tight that it scrapes. I believe t-glase is also FDA approved so I'm not too concerned about any plastic bits that might scrape off. For non-FDA-rated materials or larger tampers I'd recommend using the loose fit version, which is 52mm. You may see a little coffee getting past the tamper with that one.

I recommend unlocking the guide from the basket holder and removing it before you pull the tamper, otherwise you may create a vacuum and pull the coffee back out of the basket.

title: Xcarriage modification to attach Mendel extruder to BFB hot end

description.text:
WHY: BFB hot ends are very robust and easily obtainable. BFB even sell them assembled and with various nozzle sizes. They are aluminium+peek+teflon so very strong hence you can use them not only for ABS and PLA but also for HDPE, LDPE, PP, uPVC and some other materials.
WHAT: x-carriage has to be changed (to accommodate for the size of the bfb hot end) and the adapter has to be installed between extruder and xcarriage

• print one of each
  • assemble xcarriage per manual
  • the upper 2 trapped nuts will have to be heat pressed into x-carriage upper
  • attach the bfb hot end to the adapter using 2 M5 screws so that "flat" part of the acrylic is to the longer side of the hole so that 2 m3 heads can be secured in the 2 remaining holes
  • press the hot end carefully into xcarriage
  • screw the extruder to the xcarriage trough the adapter

description.text:
Replacement wheel for a child's toy stroller. Suitable for axles that end with a rivet head.
So, after my first attempt (thing:16040) the cheap plastic stroller died. fortunately we were able to find an almost identical one with metal pipe construction.
Unfortunately a wheel was broken. Even more unfortunately the new wheel had been riveted onto the axle so the axle ended in a dome.
To get around this I redesigned the wheel with a two part collar that fits around the axle, the wheel force fits around that and holds it together. It worked perfectly in the first print. The photo is the wheel after a few months of use.

Adjust the OpenSCAD file for your toy's axle width, wheel radius and thickness. Print the wheel, print two collar parts.
Clip the two collar parts over the axle, force fit the wheel over them and viola! It's ready to roll.

description.text:
I changed two things,
first) I added a parameter so that the shaft sizes on the two ends can be different.
second) I changed to using a 'pinch ring' for mouting to the shaft.

In this case the pinch ring is a Nut that I have drilled the threads out of, and tapped a screw into the side of. Iprefer this as it puts compressive load on teh plastic and dosn't try to stretch it. So far I'v had really good success with this method.

Add a small magnet in the bottom of the hole to hold the bit.

Who hasn't been annoyed when someone tips over your stack of ships in the warp when retrieving one of theirs?

This is a ship holder for cosmic encounters, FFG edition, designed to hold all 20 ships and has a lugged cap shaped like one of the ships modified from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2004269.

Its designed as you throw them in there (I tip them sideways and insert into the window) so they align. On your turn, you can easily fish one out as the windows are full length and you grab it with your thumb and forefinger.

The windows allow you to see who has the fewest/most in the warp when the tubes are sitting side by side. Also, there are diamonds cut in the side so you can easily count your and other's ships in the warp by 4s.

This turned out a bit big, "300" is about 8cm wide.
I found that printing this at 75% scale makes it more suitable as a keychain.

title: InMoov robot Arm modified to click a Tally Counter

description.text:
We wanted to create a art piece called "Humans not need to count" talking about all jobs lose by robots and a the same time question if humans need to do repetitive and boring tasks as a job.

We modified some parts of the hand and forearm to be able to hold the tally counter and press it. We use a fishing line and a strong DC motor(https://www.pololu.com/product/2826) outside of the arm since force it need it is quite strong. Fishing line pass through the ring finger. We did a holder to be able to attached directly to the wall. Wrist and all fingers except of the thumb are fix position to hold nice the tally counter. The thumb was slightly modify to reach the position to click the tally counter that is quite close to palm of the hand.

You can see a demo video here: https://youtu.be/cnDQ1G789YM

Arduino code it is published here: https://github.com/var-mar/HumansNeedNotCount

title: Flux Capacitor Charger Wall Mount Adapter

description.text:
I recently got a ThinkGeek Flux Capacitor USB car charger. Since I already have a USB port in my car, I though it would be more useful to mount in on the wall above my desk instead. I designed this adapter to replace the existing cigarette lighter plug which comes with the charger, allowing you to power the charger off of a 12V DC wall adapter.

FreeCAD source file included, feel free to use and modify it as desired.

Assembly Instructions
  • Remove the 6 screws on the back of the charger. The front and back halves of the charger should pull apart. The on/off button will also be free now. Set the top and the button aside.
  • Desolder the red and black wires in the lower right corner of the board. These wires go to the cigarette lighter plug.
  • Remove the two screws holding the plug on to the charger. Pull the plug off, guiding the wires out as necessary.
  • Thread new wires through the back of the charger and the mount you just printed. Trim to length and strip the ends.
  • Solder the wires down to the charger board.
  • Press the new mount on to the back of the charger. Attach it using the screws that you previously removed from the cigarette lighter plug. Do not overtighten these screws, as this will tend to crack the printed plastic.
  • Solder the barrel jack on to the wires. Typically you'll want the center pin to be positive. I do not know if this charger has reverse input protection or not.
  • At this point, it might not be a bad idea to plug in your wall adapter and verify that everything is working. You may have to press the on/off button after applying power to get the lights to turn on.
  • Once you're satisfied that it works, use hot-melt glue to secure the barrel jack into the mount.
  • Re-attach the front of the charger.

To use the full capacity of the charger, you will need a 12V/2A adapter. If you are only charging small devices, or just want to make it light up, a 12V/1A adapter will probably be fine.

Several different styles of DC barrel jack should work. You can get them on eBay by searching for "2.1mm DC Jack". Digikey part CP-024A-ND should also work.

title: LED Mounts Flexible & Modular for MP Select Mini & Others

description.text:
This is version 1 of my Flexible Modular LED Mounts. I am working on a version 2 which has a slimmer profile due to a simplified, streamlined back cover.
I originally designed these LED mounts for the Monoprice Mini Select but they can be used to clamp onto any piece of material up to 1mm thick.
I decided to add some light to my printing bed after I started using black filament on BuildTak which is incredibly hard to see those first few crucial layers go down.
These mounts hold standard 5mm LEDs which should snap in with no glue needed. Each mount has 2 wire guides to keep your wires need and give the back cover something to snap onto. I designed several clamps for mounting the LEDs and I designed the side mounting clamps in a low profile all-in-one LED mount unit and a separate clamp that can attach a LED link for added flexibility. I tried to make the system as modular as possible to allow endless combinations of clamps and lights. I also designed a wire guide which has a reverse part as well. The wire guides use the same modular clamps as the LED links.
Please feel free to remix, reuse, and come up with your own variations of the LED links. Don't forget to upload your pics of how you used the links to help give others ideas on their own custom LED light setups.

UPDATES
2-6 Fixed Shell CR & CL for tighter fit. Noticed clamps are tighter than they need to be so will loosen up for Rev. 2. Shells don't play nice when really close to metal frame but that is also fixed in Rev. 2.

author: BridMari3D

title: flsun nozzle tip cooler v3.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Version 1.0:
I had to design a more uniform filament cooler duct for the nozzle tip. This is designed to be mounted with two m3 screws that can be installed through the existing lower holes for the extruder cooling fan. Nuts are not required but can be used if you strip the plastic following the print.

Flow simulation was also performed to ensure that uniform air flow was distributed around the nozzle tip. I will be working on improvements as the comments roll in. Also, I plan on incorporating a couple iterations of this including an extruder fan duct, a bltouch sensor adapter, and maybe a LED holder.

https://youtu.be/vkgaAB0Zlcc

Update - Version 1.1:
I had some time to refine this a bit more, so these are the listed updates:

  • duct adapter to fan exhaust only has one flap for alignment
  • overall duct brought lower to bring cooling closer to nozzle tip
  • changed profile of exhaust ports on inner diameter to direct air down directly towards nozzle tip
  • diameter for holes for M3 screws changed to 3mm so a nut won't be necessary to tighten to fan

I haven't yet decided if V2.0 will be an adapter including a bltouch mount or the hot end duct. Depending on demand through comments, I will prioritize accordingly. Thank you for everyone's feedback and support on this!

Updated v3.0 - Mar 3 2017:
Since some people have upgraded their extruders, I've made this modification so those users can mount the cooler on the gantry bracket with the top screw holes. Enjoy!
I've also updated another file, v3.0 with an open front so you can see the print and nozzle tip. I've also simplified the exhaust with two larger ports on either side which actually performs the same overall.

comments.text: All designs I have seen so far so not decrease the flow path area the further away from the fan (as you loose flow through the nozzles, the smaller the ring area has to become or better said when you loose mass flow over nozzles, the ring area has to decrease otherwise the flow slows down in the ring). Your design channels the flow and divides those flows over segments, correct?
